shift.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to move from one place or position to another, or make something do this
shift.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Joe listened, shifting uncomfortably from one foot to another.
She shifted her gaze from me to Bobby.
shift.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to move something, especially by picking it up and carrying it
shift.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Give me a hand to shift these chairs.
shift.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to change a situation, discussion etc by giving special attention to one idea or subject instead of to a previous one
shift.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: In this stage of a rape case, the focus often shifts onto the victim and her conduct.
It’s hard to shift gear when you come home after a busy day at work.
The White House hopes to shift the media’s attention away from foreign policy issues.
shift.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if someone’s opinions, beliefs etc shift, they change
shift.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Public opinion was beginning to shift to the right  (=become more right-wing).
He refused to shift his ground (=change his opinion).
shift.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to change the way that money is paid or spent
shift.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: the need to shift more resources towards reducing poverty
shift.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to remove dirt or marks from a surface or piece of clothing
shift.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: a new washing powder that will shift any stain
shift.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to change the gears when you are driving
shift.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to sell a product, especially a lot of it
shift.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: The store shifted over 1,000 copies of the book last week.
shift.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a change in the way people think about something, in the way something is done etc
shift.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: a marked shift (=noticeable change) in attitudes towards women
the shift from one type of economic system to another
shift.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if workers in a factory, hospital etc work shifts, they work for a particular period of time during the day or night, and are then replaced by others, so that there are always people working
shift.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: A shift system has been introduced.
Dave had to work a 12-hour shift yesterday.
The thought of working night shifts put her off becoming a nurse.
I’m on the early shift tomorrow.
shift.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: the workers who work during one of these periods
shift.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: before the early shift goes off duty
shift.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: To run the spell-checker, press SHIFT and F7.
shift.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a simple straight loose-fitting woman’s dress
